Package com.martinandersson.javaee.jpa.mapping.elementcollection

JPA 2.1, section "2.6 Collections of Embeddable Classes and Basic Types":

See: Description

  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    ElementCollectionDefaultMappingTest
    Fails on WildFly/Hibernate (8.1.0 and 8.2.0).
    ElementCollectionSeparateTableTest  

Package com.martinandersson.javaee.jpa.mapping.elementcollection Description

JPA 2.1, section "2.6 Collections of Embeddable Classes and Basic Types": 

 
     A persistent field or property of an entity or embeddable class may
     correspond to a collection of a basic type or embeddable class ("element
     collection"). Such a collection, when specified as such by the
     ElementCollection annotation, is mapped by means of a collection table,
     as defined in Section 11.1.8. If the ElementCollection annotation (or XML
     equivalent) is not specified for the collection-valued field or property,
     the rules of Section 2.8 apply.
Section 2.8 doesn't list the field type Set. Section "11.1.14 ElementCollection Annotation" says: 

 
     The ElementCollection annotation (or equivalent XML element) must be
     specified if the collection is to be mapped by means of a collection
     table.
My understanding of section 2.6 and 11.1.14 is that @ElementCollection is optional and may be left out. Only if added shall the collection be mapped to his own table. GlassFish and EclipseLink work in this way, WildFly and Hibernate crash upon deployment.

In order to make at least one of the provided two tests work on WildFly (the one that uses @ElementCollection; ElementCollectionSeparateTableTest), they have been split into separate files and separate deployments.

Using Arquillian's techniques for multiple deployments (i.e. @Deployment(name = "name") and @OperateOnDeployment("name")) won't bypass this issue.

Bug filed here: 


 
     https://hibernate.atlassian.net/browse/HHH-9402
